This weekend I am visiting Selma, Alabama with Representative John Lewis and many of my colleagues in the House.   As many of you know, Selma, Alabama, played an integral role in our nation’s Civil Rights Movement. On January 2, 1965, Martin Luther King Jr., SCLC, SNCC, and other local African American activists led a voting rights campaign in Selma because the Alabama governor at the time, George Wallace, and the local county sheriff in Dallas County led a steadfast opposition to black voter registration drives.   At the time, John Lewis was the leader of Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC), and led the Selma to Montgomery march across the Edmund Pettus Bridge on March 7, 1965. John Lewis and the protestors were met with state troopers and troopers on horseback and were attacked. Two days after “Bloody Sunday,” King led a group of 2,000 protestors, including clergy; and they walked across the Edmund Pettus Bridge, prayed and marched back to Selma, Alabama. Shortly thereafter, President Lyndon Baines Johnson would introduce voting rights legislation. On August 6, 1965, President Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act of 1965.   Without the Voting Rights Act of 1965, African Americans and other minorities would be barred from voting and continue to have limited civil rights.   Just like those many years ago, today during these incredibly divisive times we are being called upon  to speak out against intolerance and speak up for what is right.

During my visit to Selma, we stopped at the Dexter Avenue King Memorial Baptist Church, where the Montgomery Bus Boycott was organized. Standing outside of the Dexter Avenue Baptist Church I was reminded of President Barack Obama's words when he spoke at the 50th anniversary of "Bloody Sunday". President Obama said, "Selma shows us that America is not the project of any one person. Because the single most powerful word in our democracy is the word 'We.' We the people. We shall overcome. Yes we can."   Today we recognize and can see the great progress we have made as a nation, but our work still continues. #Selma #DexterAvenueBaptistChurch

I have been visiting medical centers and hospitals throughout the 2nd Congressional District since I arrived in Congress. From Lankenau to Temple Hospital to Einstein and many other stops in between, I have spoken with doctors, nurses and patients to listen to everyone’s perspective on our nation’s health care system. Yesterday, I visited DaVita Dialysis Center as a part of my #PA02 hospital tour. I want to tell you a story about my friend, Ms. Jones.   Ms. Jones has been on dialysis for the last two years and receives her weekly care from DaVita. She comes in for treatment for several hours a day, three to four times a week to get her dialysis. Even though Ms. Jones is in a tough situation, she has an incredible spirit and shared with me how if she didn’t have help from the state and wasn’t benefiting from the #ACA she wouldn’t be able to get the care she needs. Ms. Jones worked hard for many years and earned a livable wage but now lives on a fixed income and needs help to pay for her medicine.   When we think about how the health care debate in Congress impacts the quality of life for Philadelphians we are talking about people like Ms. Jones. We know health care is a matter of access. If you don’t have the financial means you don’t have access to quality care. Ms. Jones’ story is like so many of our stories. We need to stand united as citizens and come together around a health care plan that makes our neighborhoods less divided and more united.   I will continue to be vocal in my opposition of the Republican American Health Care Act #AHCA as it does NOT provide affordable #healthcare to millions of Americans.

Today, The Hill published my joint op-ed with Congressman Adriano Espaillat about our bill, the No Federal Funding for Confederate Symbols Act.   As many of you know, the events that took place in Charlottesville, Virginia, were hateful and unacceptable. These events did however catalyze a national conversation around Confederate symbols in our country.   Confederate symbols, such as the battle flag and monuments, were built between the late 19th century and early 20th century, during the Jim Crow Era. They weren’t created to “honor” anyone’s heritage, but instead were constructed to terrorize African-Americans and remind people in the South that if the Civil War had not ended as it did, slavery would still exist today.  American history includes African-Americans—our suffering and our survival. The 1,503 symbols of the Confederacy in public spaces, must go! They do not serve any purpose, and only stand as a reminder to communities of color that they are not welcome on a land their ancestors built and fought for.

Octavius V. Catto was an educator, scholar, baseball player, and civil rights activist in Philadelphia.  He fought to desegregate trolley cars in our City, to integrate baseball and increase voting & educational opportunities for African-Americans.  On October 10, 1871, on Election Day in Philadelphia, he was tragically shot and killed on the streets of Lombard & South Street—just a few steps away from his home.  His funeral was held in the City Armory at Broad and Race Streets and his family, friends, colleagues, and many more attended his funeral to mourn Octavius death but also to acknowledge his incredible accomplishments and contributions to the civil rights movement!   Now more than 140 years later and on #VoterRegistrationDay, Octavius V. Catto is finally being honored and remembered in our City. I am very proud to see my friend and colleague, Mayor Jim Kenney unveil the Catto statue earlier today, which as you know is Philadelphia’s first ever statue to commemorate an African American.  I applaud those who fought for years in order for this statue to become a reality for Philadelphians and our county as a whole.

Today in History: On October 16, 1995 hundreds of thousands of black men joined together in our Nation's Capitol for the Million Man March. They stood together, united for what would become the largest civil rights demonstration in our nation's history. When we come together, take a close look at what is happening around us and stand strong in unison, we can and will achieve all we set out to accomplish to make our neighborhoods stronger together.

Rev. Leon H. Sullivan was a prominent civil rights leader and social activist; he believed jobs were the key to the economic development and empowerment of African-Americans.   Unfortunately, many companies were not in favor of hiring African-Americans during the civil rights movement. Therefore, he organized what we think to be 400 ministers to boycott companies who did not believe in equal opportunity employment. His slogan, “Don’t buy where you don’t work” was extremely successful and led to similar boycotts around the country. His actions provided over 5,000 jobs in #Philadelphia, #Pennsylvania.   While the boycott was successful, Rev. Leon H. Sullivan realized that some African-Americans were not trained and prepared for their new jobs. To make sure they would have the skills necessary to keep and retain these jobs, he founded the Opportunities Industrialization Centers of America.   His dedication to communities of color and creating an organization that help people obtain the skills needed to succeed, is still an incredible model for cities across our country!   Heroes, like Rev. Leon H. Sullivan did not get enough recognition for the ground work they helped lay for people like me, who want to help build stronger neighborhoods block by block. That is why, I am so proud to share that this week a state historical marker was placed in North Philadelphia to honor Rev. Sullivan and his impact on our neighborhoods!    It was wonderful to attend the ceremony with leaders in our City who understand the importance of Rev. Sullivan’s work and celebrate his accomplishments that continue to inspire generations to create positive change in America in the face of adversity.
